    Olympics

    Unlikely Skeleton Duo Share an Obscure Sport and a Crazy Dream

    By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLDFEB. 15, 2018

    Continue reading the main story Share This Page
    Continue reading the main story

    PYEONGCHANG, South Korea — They are united here, at the Winter Games, at the bottom ranks of a sport considered among the most dangerous and daring, flopping belly first on a heavy sled and rocketing headfirst down a twisting and swirling ice track at 80 miles an hour.

    It’s called skeleton, not because of what may break, but because of the bony appearance of the sled (or from a corruption of a Norwegian word for sled, “kjaelke”). Some call it plain crazy.

    The two skeleton athletes here from Jamaica and Ghana, two countries where there is very little natural ice, if any, were apprehensive, too, at first, neither of them knowing much about the sport before giving it a shot.

    Anthony Watson, 28, a sometime actor from New Jersey representing Jamaica through his father’s lineage, recalled lying on the sled a few years ago as a training coach lifted his legs before that first run down, way down.

    Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

    “He didn’t tell me anything,” he recalled. “He was just like, ‘All right, see you at the bottom,’ and he just shoved me on the track.”

    Akwasi Frimpong, 32, a once promising track athlete in the Netherlands who immigrated there illegally from Ghana as a child and represents that country, remembers thinking on that first run: “Oh, man, I’m going to die. You want to brake, but there are no brakes. If there was a button to press stop, I would have.”

    Continue reading the main story

    Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

    But then he got to the bottom nearly a minute later, alive, and recovered his athletic instincts.

    “The competitiveness in you says why not go back up and make less mistakes and go even faster,” he said.

    Now, here they are, improbably, proudly, at the Olympics.

    They met in October 2016 at a training camp for what are called emerging countries in the sport. They became fast friends, sharing a quick laugh, skin darker than their competitors’, the bond of representing ancestral countries where they did not live and a determination to get to the Olympics in an unfamiliar sport.

    They have trained together. They have lost together. They have prayed together.

    They share a storage and preparation shed for their sleds here and also the bond of minor celebrity. They also get the same question a lot: What are you doing here?

    To which they say: This is the Olympics. What is everybody else doing here? Dreaming big, testing their limits and, in some cases, sending a message.

    “I want to break barriers, to show that people from warmer countries, black people, can do this sport as well,” Frimpong said. “I want to write the history for my country, and hope more kids come out of their comfort zone. And I want to gain experience for the next Olympics in 2022.”

    They finish each other’s sentences and have their own rituals, a handshake and chest bump of solidarity, before and after races, as a way to ground themselves in a sport in which the color of their skin makes them stand out and sometimes invites skepticism.

    Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

    “Before every run we dap up, and at the bottom we dap up, and at the end of the day we dap,” Watson said.

    There are nearly 3,000 athletes here from 92 countries. Most of them will go home empty-handed, as Watson and Frimpong surely will. They were at the very bottom of the standings before the final runs on Friday.

    Yet they demand to be taken seriously as athletes, juggling news media attention while trying to focus and train.

    “I don’t want to be just a media guy,” said Frimpong, who, like Watson, competed in the sport’s world championships last year. “I want to show I can slide as well.”

    His journey was particularly circuitous.

    He left Ghana at age 8, carried to the Netherlands by his mother, who had left five years before to work cleaning houses and selling flowers to provide for her 11 children living in a cramped house in Ghana. She had promised to send for him, but he landed in an alien European world where organized sports helped him earn acceptance.

    Newsletter Sign Up

    Continue reading the main story

    He excelled at track, gaining notice as a Dutch junior national champion at 17 in 2004, and eventually earning a scholarship to a university in Utah. But his status as an illegal immigrant initially kept him from leaving the Netherlands, until a public campaign helped smooth over the paperwork.

    He came close to making the 2012 Olympic track team for the Netherlands, but an injury kept him off and sidelined his track career. He was steered to bobsled and nearly made the 2014 Sochi Games team for the Netherlands.

    A coach suggested skeleton. It was 2015, and he was selling vacuum cleaners in Arizona, where he had moved with his wife. He knew not giving it a shot to make the Olympics again would gnaw at him.

    “It was like a bucket list thing,” he said.

    He chose Ghana, he said, because he felt he had given to two countries by then, the Netherlands and the United States, where he was engaged in charitable endeavors related to track.

    Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

    “At the age of 31, you ask, what have you done for your country?”

    Ghana was more than willing to have him, though he is getting by mostly on sponsorships. His racing helmet, showing a rabbit escaping the jaws of a lion, represents his breaking free from life’s challenges.

    Likewise, Watson struggled to make the Olympics in track, and ended up in skeleton as a last-ditch effort. He had scrolled through the qualifications for nearly every sport and found that skeleton offered walk-ons who passed physical tests a path.

    He went to a combine for the sport in Lake Placid, N.Y., and did well enough to earn a spot in an elite camp. Gradually, however, he accepted that it would be highly competitive to make the American team.

    Jamaica, with its “Cool Runnings” vibe and history of recruiting promising athletes for bobsled and skeleton, opened the way.

    He had paid the bills by working in the family furniture business and acting, even turning down a temporary spot as a hyena in “The Lion King” on Broadway so he could train for the Olympics.

    They both know skeptics and doubters remain. They read it on the faces of some athletes, but try to keep focus.

    “This is bigger than ourselves,” Watson said, as Frimpong nodded hard in agreement. “Which is why we connect so well, because you see a lot of athletes and the reason they are so depressed and on themselves and lashing out at other people is because this is literally all they have. When it’s gone they are not going to have anything.”

    But this skeleton duo insists there is more, the accolades from young fans, the awe and wonder from fans in the countries they represent.

    Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

    “We understand,” Watson said, “there is a bigger audience, and that’s why we have so much fun doing it while we are here.”

    On the last qualifying run Friday, neither advanced to the final, finishing 29th (Watson) and 30th (Frimpong) out of 30.

    Just off the track, they dapped.

    A version of this article appears in print on February 16, 2018, on Page B13 of the New York edition with the headline: ‘It Was Like a Bucket List Thing’. Order Reprints| Today's Paper|Subscribe
